statement.p:
The following prompts in this activity will lead you to develop the derivative of the inverse tangent function \arctan(x).
Write the two equations expressing the fact that \arctan is the inverse function of \tan.
Differentiate both sides of the equations you found in (a). Since we don't yet know the derivative of \arctan, wherever its derivative appears simply leave it as \arctan'.
One of the two derivative equations you found in (b) (but not the other) can be solved for \arctan'(x). Decide which of them can be so solved, and do so.
Draw a right triangle with angle \theta so that \theta = \arctan(x). What are the three sides of the triangle?
In terms of only x and 1, what is the value of \cos(\arctan(x))?
Use the results of your work above to find an expression for \arctan'(x) involving only 1 and x.

li.p: Recall that for any function f and its inverse f^{-1}, we have f^{-1}(f(x)) = x and f(f^{-1}(x)) = x.
Apply the chain rule to differentiate \tan(\arctan(x)) and \arctan(\tan(x)).
Note that we are trying to solve for \arctan'(x), not \arctan'(\tan(x)), so an equation only involving the latter is no good. Now treat \arctan'(x) as if it were a variable, say y, and solve for it.
Let the vertical leg of the triangle be x. What must the horizontal leg be?
Recall that the cosine of an angle is the length of the adjacent leg over the length of they hypotenuse.
For any function f and its inverse f^{-1}, we have f^{-1}(f(x)) = x and f(f^{-1}(x)) = x, so in this case we get \tan(\arctan(x)) = x and \arctan(\tan(y)) = y.

Differentiating \tan(\arctan(x)) = x, we have \frac{d}{dx}[\tan(\arctan(x))] = \frac{d}{dx}[x], so
\sec^2(\arctan(x)) \arctan'(x) = 1.
Differentiating \arctan(\tan(x)) = x, we have \frac{d}{dx}[\arctan(\tan(x))] = \frac{d}{dx}[x], so
\arctan'(\tan(x)) \sec^2(x) = 1.

The equation \arctan'(\tan(x)) \sec^2(x) = 1 can't be solved for \arctan(x) since it doesn't even contain \arctan(x). But for the equation \sec^2(\arctan(x)) \arctan'(x) = 1, we have
\arctan'(x) = \frac{1}{\sec^2(\arctan(x))} = \cos^2(\arctan(x)) , since \frac{1}{\sec(\alpha)} = \cos(\alpha).

Letting \theta = \arctan(x), it follows that we can view \theta as an angle in a right triangle with legs 1 and x (so that \tan(\theta) = \frac{x}{1}, and thus by the Pythagorean Theorem, the triangle's hypotenuse is \sqrt{1+x^2}, as shown below.

To evaluate \cos(\arctan(x)), we use the right triangle developed in (d) and observe that
\cos(\arctan(x)) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^2}} .

Finally, we recall that we know \arctan'(x) = \cos^2(\arctan(x)) = \left( \cos(\arctan(x)) \right)^2. Having established that \cos(\arctan(x)) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}, we now have that
\arctan'(x) = \frac{1}{1+x^2} .
